plc.project

Class Parser

  • java.lang.Object
    • plc.project.Parser

  • public final class Parser
extends java.lang.Object
    The parser takes the sequence of tokens emitted by the lexer and turns that into a structured representation of the program, called the Abstract Syntax Tree (AST). The parser has a similar architecture to the lexer, just with Tokens instead of characters. As before, peek(Object...) and match(Object...) are helpers to make the implementation easier. This type of parser is called recursive descent. Each rule in our grammar will have its own function, and reference to other rules correspond to calling that functions.

      • parseField

        public Ast.Field parseField()
                     throws ParseException
        Parses the field rule. This method should only be called if the next tokens start a field, aka LET.
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parseMethod

        public Ast.Method parseMethod()
                       throws ParseException
        Parses the method rule. This method should only be called if the next tokens start a method, aka DEF.
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parseStatement

        public Ast.Stmt parseStatement()
                        throws ParseException
        Parses the statement rule and delegates to the necessary method. If the next tokens do not start a declaration, if, while, or return statement, then it is an expression/assignment statement.
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parseDeclarationStatement

        public Ast.Stmt.Declaration parseDeclarationStatement()
                                               throws ParseException
        Parses a declaration statement from the statement rule. This method should only be called if the next tokens start a declaration statement, aka LET.
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • parsePrimaryExpression

        public Ast.Expr parsePrimaryExpression()
                                throws ParseException
        Parses the primary-expression rule. This is the top-level rule for expressions and includes literal values, grouping, variables, and functions. It may be helpful to break these up into other methods but is not strictly necessary.
        Throws:
        ParseException

      • peek

        private boolean peek(java.lang.Object... patterns)
        As in the lexer, returns true if the current sequence of tokens matches the given patterns. Unlike the lexer, the pattern is not a regex; instead it is either a Token.Type, which matches if the token's type is the same, or a String, which matches if the token's literal is the same. In other words, Token(IDENTIFIER, "literal") is matched by both peek(Token.Type.IDENTIFIER) and peek("literal").

      • match

        private boolean match(java.lang.Object... patterns)
        As in the lexer, returns true if peek(Object...) is true and advances the token stream.
